segments.text: two missing characters. That is all that
it took for researchers from Whiz to
hack into the core of the AWS console.
The researchers discovered a
vulnerability called codebach where they
noticed that within the AWS code build
web hook system, there was a set of
rules that any event must meet to
trigger a build. One of these rules was
an actor ID filter. This was an allow
list of approved GitHub user IDs that
ensures only trusted users can trigger a
build. But actor ID used an unanchored
reax filter for its verification. In the
context of reax, unanchored means the
search pattern is looking for a match
anywhere within a string rather than
requiring the whole string to match. And
because this filter wasn't anchored, any
GitHub ID that contained a substring of
the trusted ID could bypass code build
security. They just needed to obtain a
GitHub user with an ID that would match
the substring pattern. They named this
scenario an eclipse event. So the Whiz
team started creating new GitHub users
in batches until they hit that Eclipse
event. And eventually they managed to
capture a user ID that would bypass the
actor ID filter. And this enabled them
to push out a pull request to the AWS
JavaScript SDK library which in turn
enabled them to retrieve the GitHub
credentials for the project and gain
admin access to the AWS cold build
repository. Whiz of course then notified
AWS who managed to patch this issue
within 48 hours. But this just shows how
even the most robust systems built by
giant companies like Microsoft and
Amazon can still be vulnerable to minor
security flaws like a random insecure
reax pattern. If you want to hear more
security stories like this one, be sure
to subscribe to the BetterStack

fullText: two missing characters. That is all that it took for researchers from Whiz to hack into the core of the AWS console. The researchers discovered a vulnerability called codebach where they noticed that within the AWS code build web hook system, there was a set of rules that any event must meet to trigger a build. One of these rules was an actor ID filter. This was an allow list of approved GitHub user IDs that ensures only trusted users can trigger a build. But actor ID used an unanchored reax filter for its verification. In the context of reax, unanchored means the search pattern is looking for a match anywhere within a string rather than requiring the whole string to match. And because this filter wasn't anchored, any GitHub ID that contained a substring of the trusted ID could bypass code build security. They just needed to obtain a GitHub user with an ID that would match the substring pattern. They named this scenario an eclipse event. So the Whiz team started creating new GitHub users in batches until they hit that Eclipse event. And eventually they managed to capture a user ID that would bypass the actor ID filter. And this enabled them to push out a pull request to the AWS JavaScript SDK library which in turn enabled them to retrieve the GitHub credentials for the project and gain admin access to the AWS cold build repository. Whiz of course then notified AWS who managed to patch this issue within 48 hours. But this just shows how even the most robust systems built by giant companies like Microsoft and Amazon can still be vulnerable to minor security flaws like a random insecure reax pattern. If you want to hear more security stories like this one, be sure to subscribe to the BetterStack
